title: Question 148

children: A 31-year-old woman is evaluated following a wasp sting and the development of cough and dyspnea.

Blood pressure is 93/60 mm Hg, pulse rate is 109/min, and respiration rate is 28/min. Diffuse wheezing and coughing are present. No stridor, rash, or swelling of the face, tongue, or oropharynx is noted.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
The initial treatment of anaphylaxis is intramuscular epinephrine, repeated as needed every 5 to 15 minutes.
Neither antihistamines nor glucocorticoids have been shown to improve outcomes in anaphylaxis.
The most appropriate next step in treatment of this patient experiencing anaphylaxis from a hypersensitivity reaction to insect venom is intramuscular (IM) epinephrine (

). In addition, this patient should receive basic life support measures with high-flow oxygen, cardiac monitoring, recumbent positioning, and establishment of intravenous (IV) access with IV fluid administration as needed. Concerns include airway obstruction, bronchospasm, and distributive shock. Of these, the patient has evidence only of bronchospasm at this time, but she should be monitored for the other manifestations of anaphylaxis. The initial treatment of anaphylaxis is IM epinephrine, repeated as needed every 5 to 15 minutes, preferably in the anterolateral thigh. Patients with wheezing unresponsive to IM epinephrine should also receive treatment with an inhaled Î²

-agonist, such as albuterol. If airway closure appears to be a threat and is not responsive to initial treatment with epinephrine, immediate intubation of the trachea is advisable. Patients with a history of anaphylactic reactions should carry an epinephrine autoinjector, wear an alert bracelet to let responders know of their hypersensitivity, and be referred to an immunologist/allergist for possible venom immunotherapy.
Neither IV antihistamines, such as diphenhydramine (
), nor IV glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone (

), have been shown to improve outcomes in anaphylaxis, and these agents would not reverse this patient's bronchospasm quickly enough. When these agents are used, it is usually to decrease pruritus and rash or to prevent a delayed recurrence of symptoms. However, guidelines suggest against administering glucocorticoids or antihistamines as an intervention to prevent biphasic anaphylaxis.

objective.__html: Treat anaphylaxis secondary to stinging insect bite.
